title: Sky hit by ad and consumer spending crunch despite return of sport
text:
British media and telecoms group Sky became the latest company to suffer from a contraction in consumer and advertising spending in the latest quarter, amid squeezed incomes and tougher economic conditions.

The company, owned by US media conglomerate Comcast, reported a 15 per cent fall in revenues in the three months to September, to $4.3bn which was below analyst expectations of $4.4bn, though revenue was flat when taking into account currency fluctuations.

Adjusted earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation fell 16 per cent to $701mn, though this came in above consensus estimates. The decrease was largely driven by a fall in its consumer telecoms and broadcasting division, as well as its advertising income.

Philadelphia-based Comcast acquired Sky in 2018, as it sought to expand its international footprint, but the group went on to struggle with higher costs and disruptions to sports broadcasting because of the pandemic.

It is now grappling with high levels of competition against a backdrop of climbing interest rates, weaker consumer spending and significantly higher costs.

Underscoring the challenging environment in the UK, Comcast itself reported higher than anticipated revenue and earnings, with a particularly strong performance in its media and entertainment business NBCUniversal.

“At Sky, our team continues to prudently manage through a difficult and rapidly changing macroeconomic and geopolitical period in the UK and Europe,” said Brian Roberts, chair and chief executive of Comcast.

The company reported revenues of $29.9bn, above consensus estimates of $29.6bn, and adjusted ebitda of $9.5bn, above the expected $9.2bn.

Revenues in the company's studios and theme parks businesses increased by 31 and 42 per cent respectively, suggesting consumer discretionary spending has so far escaped a severe hit despite mounting fears about a global recession.

TV and music streaming companies faced a reckoning earlier this year when Netflix revealed that its subscriber growth had stalled for the first time in a decade. Comcast's Peacock streaming platform, which competes with Netflix and Disney, gained 2mn new subscribers, to reach 15mn in the latest quarter.

The US group — one of the last fully fledged media and telecoms conglomerates, offering cable and broadband alongside entertainment including films and television — reported modest growth in its bread and butter cable business, amid a challenging environment for US cable companies this year as competition intensifies and demand cools following the pandemic internet boom.

The company gained 14,000 broadband customers in the quarter, down from 300,000 in the previous three-month period, and lost 561,000 video customers. Its revenue in the sector nevertheless came in line with industry expectations, at $16.5bn.
